Recreation and Parks |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |picture = 2011 Bakersfield City Hall North.JPG |picture_width = |picture_caption = Department Headquarters |formed = {{Start date|1908}} |jurisdiction = [[Bakersfield, California]] |headquarters = [[Bakersfield City Hall|City Hall North]] |budget = $16 million (2009-10) |chief1_name = Dianne Hoover |chief1_position = Recreation and Parks Director |website = [http://www.bakersfieldcity.us/recreation/index.htm bakersfieldcity.us/recreation] }} The '''Department of Recreation and Parks''' is a department of the city of [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]], [[California]]. It is responsible for the maintenance of the city's lands which include: parks, natural preserves, and streetscapes. It also runs recreational programs throughout the year at various locations throughout the city. The department also runs the [[Bakersfield Ice Sports Center]] and [[McMurtrey Aquatic Center]]. Although there are incorporated areas in the northwest, the city does not have any parks in that region. They are instead maintained by the North of the River Recreation and Parks District. The department has been accredited by the [[Commission for Accreditation of Park and Recreation Agencies]].[http://www.bakersfieldcity.us/recreation/capra_accreditation.html CAPRA]. Bakersfield Department of Recreation and Parks. Accessed: 04-07-2011. ==History== The department was founded in 1908. That year, Truxtun Beale donated the land and finances for the development of the city's first park, which was named [[Beale Park (Bakersfield)|Beale Park]].[http://www.bakersfieldcity.us/recreation/Parks/beale.htm Beale Park]. City of Bakersfield Recreation & Parks. Accessed: 04-07-2011. The departments role was simple, to provide maintenance for the city's parks. Two more parks would be donated, before the first park was constructed on land purchased by the city, which was [[Jefferson Park (Bakersfield)|Jefferson Park]] in [[East Bakersfield]]. By 1940, the city would have five parks.[http://www.bakersfieldcity.us/weblink7/ElectronicFile.aspx?docid=771599&dbid=0 Rehabilitate Bakersfield Right]. Bakersfield Historic Preservation Commission. Accessed: 04-07-2011. In 1964, a community center was constructed in [[Mill Creek|Central Park]]. It would be the first item for the department to manage that was not a park. Also, starting in the 1960's was a requirement that developers plan a set amount of park space per acre developed. With the large population growth that started in the early 1970's, the amount of land that needed maintenance would also greatly increase. Also, with the purchase of assets from Tenneco West in 1976, would create the largest park in the city, the [[Kern River Parkway]]. The parkway would initially start at 2,900 acres and would eventually grow to over 6,000 acres.[http://www.bakersfieldcity.us/cityservices/water/pdfs/kernriverpur.pdf The Kern River Purchase]. City of Bakersfield. December 2003. Page: 21. Accessed: 04-07-2011. Starting in the 1990's the department would see another area of responsibility grow. The city started requiring developers to landscape major arterials adjacent to their developments. Also, streetscape projects [[Downtown Bakersfield|downtown]] would result in more landscaping that needed to be maintained. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External Links== *[http://www.bakersfieldcity.us/recreation/index.htm Bakersfield Department of Recreation and Parks] {{Parks in Bakersfield}} {{Government of Bakersfield}} [[Category:Government of Bakersfield, California|d]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 1908]]
